channel.title: Daily Feed (Last 48 Hours, Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Last 48 Hours, Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: The Look of Empire
item.description: Donald Trump’s dangerous fixation with imperial aesthetics.

item.title: As combat evolves, leaders seek not ‘super-athletes’ but ‘human weapon systems’
item.description: The military wants to measure and build the ability to perform missions, not just do pushups.

item.title: Trump Launches ‘Board of Peace’ in Davos
item.description: With nearly 25 countries already signed on, critics fear that the new body could challenge the United Nations’ authority.

item.title: Carney Come Lately
item.description: The Canadian leader’s Davos speech is a masterclass in realism—and an overdue admission of hypocrisy.

item.title: The Board of Discord
item.description: Trump’s “Board of Peace” is neither an alternative to the U.N. nor a harmless vanity project but a threat to international cooperation.

item.title: DOE seeks batteries with four times the juice
item.description: Six teams will get money to build manufacturable prototypes in two years.

item.title: Bombing Iran would shore up its regime
item.description: External attacks stir up nationalism and redirect public anger outward, a “rally-around-the-flag” effect long documented by political scientists.

item.title: Russian hybrid warfare has become indistinguishable from politics
item.description: The war of realities in 2026 will determine the reality of war in 2027.

item.title: TACOs in Greenland?
item.description: The U.S. president followed up a concerning speech with a confusing announcement.

item.title: Europe Is the U.S. Establishment’s Last Hope
item.description: Trump’s Greenland spectacle has liberal-minded Americans rooting for the other guy.

item.title: Trump’s Greenland Obsession Is Madness. Can’t We Just Say That?
item.description: The commentariat persists in misrepresenting the U.S. president and his actions.

item.title: India-Germany Relations: Kite Flying at a Time of Geopolitical Flux
item.description: Amid current geopolitical shifts, the Germany-India strategic embrace has gained fresh momentum.

item.title: Kazkahstan, Uzbekistan Sign On to Trump’s ‘Board of Peace’
item.description: Central Asia’s two largest states have both sought to court the famously temperamental and transactional U.S. president.

item.title: Is China’s Economic Policy Too Cautious?
item.description: Recognizing that the old growth model has run its course, China’s leaders have embraced a measured economic strategy, focused on “high-quality development,” stability, and risk management. But they must not be so cautious that they fail to address the imbalances that may become hard constraints on the economy's long-term prospects.

item.title: How Israel Is Navigating International Boycotts
item.description: Economy Minister Nir Barkat: “We’ll do better business in places that want us.”

item.title: AI and the Future of Education
item.description: The central challenge for educators in the age of AI is to prepare students to operate effectively in the face of uncertainty. The answer is not to train them for specific tasks that may soon become obsolete, but to make them as adaptable and intellectually independent as possible.

item.title: The D Brief: Trump backs down on Greenland; More troops prep for MN deployment; Army tank arrives early; Congress demands Golden Dome answers; And a bit more.
Trump’s Golden Dome Is No Silver Bullet
item.description: Nearly one year on, one of the biggest U.S. defense proposals remains little more than a concept.

item.title: Appeasing Trump Only Invites Betrayal - as Europe’s Far Right Just Learned
item.description: With Donald Trump laying claim to Greenland, Europeans have finally realized who they are dealing with. The US president is animated less by the prospect of deal-making than by the need for domination, less by the spirit of exchange than by the perverse pleasure of belittling others and exalting himself.

item.title: How Weak Flag Oversight Is Undermining the Legitimacy of Pacific Island States
item.description: Several Pacific Island nations have acquired particular reputations for lax oversight of their flag registries.

item.title: How Science Parks Can Transform Australian Universities into Innovation Hubs
item.description: University-based science parks could become highly attractive sites for deeper engagement with industry, venture capitalists, and start-ups, and help procure government funding too.

item.title: How North Korea Views the NATO-US Rift Over Greenland
item.description: Pyongyang was oddly quiet over the U.S. military action in Venezuela – but it’s been outspoken about U.S. threats to seize control of Greenland.

item.title: Trump’s Greenland threat has already hurt US security—but far worse may come
item.description: A hostile takeover would shatter America’s key alliance, limit its military’s global reach, and invite economic reprisal.

item.title: Japan’s Southwest Islands in Focus at Latest Japan-US Defense Minister Meeting
item.description: The Japanese islands closest to Taiwan are an increasingly focal point for the Japan-U.S. alliance.

item.title: Leaked Audio Highlights Internal Rift Within the Taliban Ranks
item.description: The long-discussed rift between the Taliban’s Kabul and Kandahar factions has become more apparent than ever.

item.title: South Korean President Keeps Hope Alive for North Korea Dialogue
item.description: In a New Year press conference, South Korean President Lee Jae-myung reiterated his intention to push forward North Korea-U.S. talks, as well as inter-Korean relations.

item.title: Targeted Attacks on Chinese Nationals in Afghanistan: A Wake-Up Call for Beijing?
item.description: There's been an uptick in attacks targeting Chinese nationals – including the latest, a suicide bombing at a Chinese restaurant in Kabul.

item.title: What’s a good man worth in China’s marriage market?
item.description: A viral social-media post reveals uncomfortable realities

item.title: Which Chinese provinces splash their cash?
item.description: The misers and spendthrifts are surprising

item.title: Uganda’s opposition leader is on the run
item.description: After a disputed election, Bobi Wine is getting death threats from the president’s son

item.title: How the Kurds lost control of north-eastern Syria
item.description: Once America’s ally, a Kurdish-led militia is no longer considered useful

item.title: Trump’s grandiose peace plans may spell more pain for Gaza
item.description: A new technocratic government for Gaza has not even been allowed to enter the strip

item.description: A way to tackle the tricky economics of drugs designed for one person

item.description: From denial to bargaining to acceptance that the world has changed

item.description: In freezing temperatures, Russian drones threaten to cut off Kyiv’s power

item.description: If successful, it would mark a big leap for the European space industry

item.title: In Australia, the Liberal-National Coalition Splits, Again
item.description: While the hate crimes legislation may have been the trigger, there is a broader conflict bubbling within conservative politics.

item.title: Why AI Is Unlike Previous Tech Booms
item.description: The rise of AI follows a fundamentally different competitive logic than earlier technological revolutions. With massive capital requirements, high operating expenses, low switching costs, and intensifying regulatory scrutiny, success will depend less on scale and more on financial resilience and political influence.

item.title: Will Uzbekistan Finally Solve the Problem of Forced Labor Through Mechanization?
item.description: Isolated cases of forced labor point to deeper structural contradictions in how cotton production in Uzbekistan is still managed.

item.title: India, UAE Embark on a Strategic Defense Partnership
item.description: Will it force India to take sides in civil wars, where its friends support opposing parties in conflict?

item.title: Scott Bessent Is in Denial – and the Bond Market Is Watching
item.description: Far from warning Donald Trump against undermining foreign investors’ confidence in the US, his Treasury secretary is backing the president and downplaying the risks of a bond selloff. But markets are telling a different story.

item.title: The US in Brief: Thaw over Greenland
item.description: Our daily political update, featuring the stories that matter

item.title: The odd thing about Modi’s mojo
item.description: Constraints make India’s prime minister govern better

item.title: Homegrown apps are making dating in India less awkward
item.description: AI tools compose love poems on behalf of tongue-tied suitors

item.title: Who really won the war between India and Pakistan?
item.description: The dispute over that dispute bodes ill for the next fight

item.title: The ascent of India’s economy
item.description: It has benefited from a slice of luck, a commitment to economic reform and a shove from Donald Trump

item.title: Donald Trump’s expansionist itch has undermined global security
item.description: He has suspended his predation of Greenland, but he cannot retract the mistrust it generated

item.title: Unpacking Indonesia’s 2025 Fiscal Revenue Shortfall
item.description: Last year the country ran a budget deficit of 2.92 percent, the largest in two decades outside of the COVID-19 pandemic.

item.title: "Cover-Up": An Engaging Documentary on What it Takes to Expose CIA Misdeeds
item.description: The legendary Seymour Hersh is the subject of a new film from award-winning Snowden chronicler Laura Poitras and former ABC documentarian Mark Obenhaus.

item.title: Trump’s Board of Peace is a distraction from the real work in Gaza
item.description: America’s president has unusual power to impose peace; he must continue to use it

item.title: The Folly of Fatalism in Gaza
item.description: To broker peace, America should draw on its past successes in the Middle East.

item.title: How the Iranian Regime Breaks
item.description: Elite fracture will come gradually and then suddenly.

item.title: Vietnam’s Communist Party Votes to Cut Short 14th National Congress
item.description: The decision likely reflects a broad unanimity about the reappointment of Party chief To Lam to a second five-year term.

item.title: Boxing Day Tragedy in Indonesia Highlights Lax Boat Safety
item.description: The drowning of four Spanish nationals near the popular Komodo National Park has dealt a blow to Indonesia’s ambition to expand its tourism sector beyond Bali.

item.title: Europe Needs Joint Financing and Procurement to Defend Itself
item.description: Despite rising military spending, the European Union’s defence capabilities remain constrained by fragmented procurement, uneven national budgets and weak coordination. Bolstering resilience and reducing dependence on the United States will require mobilising resources at the European level.

item.title: The UK and Trump’s National Security Strategy
item.description: Europe will require new leadership as the US tilts from law to power.

item.title: Indonesian Rupiah Touches New Low Amid Worries of Central Bank Independence
item.description: The nomination of President Prabowo Subianto's nephew to the board of Bank Indonesia has added to the uncertainties surrounding Indonesia's economic trajectory.

item.title: Vietnam is Close to Launching Its Own Version of a China-Style Social Credit System
item.description: The country's government has consistently looked to China, its largest trading partner and ideological ally, for techniques for controlling the online activity of its citizens.
